I am not a doctor, but from what I understand about the conditions, it kind of makes sense that it would work for Arthritis but not Multiple Sclerosis.

Arthritis is largely a localized damage in particular joints that triggers inflammation there. The local condition is sending a trigger to the central nervous system that there is an issue, then the CNS is sending back signals to increase inflammation to try to fix it. The bee venom could theoretically trick the local area to not send that initial signal. It is already inflamed from the bee venom, it doesn't need to send the signal to the brain that would trigger the inflammation to fix its issue.

The symptoms of MS are a result of lesions on the spinal cord and brain, not a localized condition. With MS, there is no initial signal being sent to the CNS, the damage of the lesion on the CNS is causing it to errantly send signals to the local area telling it to be inflamed.

Look, I get that there are legitimate and important uses for bee venom, especially for people who are highly allergic. But people who go the "natural" live bee venom therapy route, y'all need to think about how objectively cruel that is. Whereas most bees survive a stinging, honey bees are particularly delicate and often die in a pretty horrible way--their stingers get stuck in humans' thick skin; the bee frantically tries to pull itself free, and in doing so, it will rip itself apart and fly off to die of massive abdominal rupture. It's one thing if a honey bee stings you by accident and dies as a result--it can't be helped. But this involves deliberately baiting/frightening bees into stinging, resulting in their deaths, for dubious therapeutic value.
A trail is Korea? Which Korea? False Korea (American occupied “Korea”) or True DPRK Korea?

Upside: One natural sting can bring years of relief. Downside: Previously un-allergic individuals (myself included) can exhibit life threatening allergic reaction from one sting to the next. The arthritis I had as a teen didn't bother me nearly as much over the course of 40 years and about 17 stings while working in sting hazard outdoor jobs. The last 3 stings have me packing antidote from now on. No more for me bartender. I've had my fill.

I do not suggest this but I've done this bee venom therapy  before, by my self. I heard from a TV show that it relieves stiffness of the joint and all stuff mentioned here. Coincidentally, a beehive was starting to grow over one of out tree in the backyard. I was below 15 years old back then but I do feel stiffness in my fingers. It's not painful but it's stiff and wont move easily and if I try to straighten my fingers, the last joints would have a weird curve to them. So, long story short, I carefully captured one bee and let it sting me without even thinking it could potentially kill me, I was 15 and alone in the house. It hurts a lot but few days later I can feel the effect already. My fingers stiffness were gone and there's hardly any curve now. Even to this day I can feel its effect though I can feel a slight stiffness developing. I was surprised with the result but knowing the possible consequences, I don't recommend this unless you're really out of options.

I’m hypothesizing (really just guessing) that it isn’t a compound in the venom - it’s the immune response. If you suffer from something that causes inflammation or an over-active immune response, could directing your immune system elsewhere lower the body’s misdirection? In other words, maybe the bee venom (and possibly any other allergy inducing substance) overtax the immune system - effectively reducing inflammation in the healthier tissues and joints, forcing action onto the more immediately threat? A type of immunity hack maybe? Just a thought - completely ungrounded in evidence or medical expertise.
